column2: The author of this book, who regrets the necessity of mentioning himself, has been absent from Paris for many years.
column3: The author of this book, who regrets the necessity of mentioning himself, has been absent from Paris for many years.

column2: Paris has been transformed since he quitted it.
column3: Paris has been transformed since he quitted it.

column2: There is no need for him to say that he loves Paris: Paris is his mind's natal city.
column3: There is no need for him to say that he loves Paris: Paris is his mind's natal city.

column2: He must be permitted to speak of that Paris as though it still existed.
column3: He must be permitted to speak of that Paris as though it still existed.

column2: May we, then, be permitted to speak of the past in the present?
column3: May we, then, be permitted to speak of the past in the present?

column2: That said, we beg the reader to take note of it, and we continue.
column3: That said, we beg the reader to take note of it, and we continue.

column2: Jean Valjean instantly quitted the boulevard and plunged into the streets, taking the most intricate lines which he could devise, returning on his track at times, to make sure that he was not being followed.
column3: Jean Valjean instantly quitted the boulevard and plunged into the streets, taking the most intricate lines which he could devise, returning on his track at times, to make sure that he was not being followed.

column2: This manoeuvre is peculiar to the hunted stag.
column3: This manoeuvre is peculiar to the hunted stag.

column2: The moon was full that night.
column3: The moon was full that night.

column2: He did not, perhaps, take sufficiently into consideration the fact that the dark side escaped him.
column3: He did not, perhaps, take sufficiently into consideration the fact that the dark side escaped him.

column2: Cosette walked on without asking any questions.
column3: Cosette walked on without asking any questions.

column2: Moreover,--and this is a remark to which we shall frequently have occasion to recur,--she had grown used, without being herself aware of it, to the peculiarities of this good man and to the freaks of destiny.
column3: Moreover,--and this is a remark to which we shall frequently have occasion to recur,--she had grown used, without being herself aware of it, to the peculiarities of this good man and to the freaks of destiny.

column2: And then she was with him, and she felt safe.
column3: And then she was with him, and she felt safe.
